metadata.titel_preek: The Scroll That Would Not Be Shredded

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The recovery and preservation of the 'Scroll' (Word of God) which demands the reformation of a complacent and self-indulgent social organization (the Church/Israel).

subject.identificatie: The Scroll / The Word of God (Semi-autonomous agency)
tekstueel_bewijs: The scroll keeps reemerging with its serious voice of truth
these two scrolls refuse to be shredded
They insist upon being taken seriously

object.identificatie: Reformation (Re-formulation of the community according to its true character)
tekstueel_bewijs: re-form and re-formulate and re-shape according to its true character
recover the church from its toxic self-indulgence
summons and the warning that had been voiced by Jeremiah
for the sake of the neighborhood
Israel had a fresh chance to be God’s faithful people
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies with the Subject (the one called to act/reform) rather than the passive Receiver of a finished work.

tekstueel_bewijs: dramatic work of Martin Luther who called the church
Josiah... instituted a policy of re-forming Israel
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Sender/Source, but the human actors are the primary 'Helpers' of the Scroll's mission.
helper.rol_van_geest: Absent; the power resides in the 'truth-telling' of the text itself.

tekstueel_bewijs: the greed system of our society does not want neighborliness
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is primarily a sociological and psychological state of the community (anxiety, greed, exclusion) rather than a cosmic or ontological power.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The individual's response to the neighbor as a manifestation of the Gospel.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon treats the 'Gospel' as the motivation for the secondary program, but the primary program (Reformation) is itself defined as the secondary program (Ethics). The two are fused.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has opened our hearts (implied context)
God... poured out for all the neighbors
voorbeelden_mens_subject: Josiah wanted to clean things up
we believe ourselves to be the especially chosen

voorbeelden: Josiah wanted to clean things up
the church... preoccupied with its survival
He saw that the church in his time was deformed
leaves us free and unencumbered (brief mention)

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'Obligation' (Devoir). It assumes that once the 'Truth' (Savoir) is presented via the Scroll, the Church 'Must' (Devoir) act. There is little attention to how an 'anxious' and 'greedy' subject receives the 'Power' (Pouvoir) to change.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Deformation) to ~S1 (Shredding) to S1 (Reformation via the Neighbor).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'Staying Power' of the Scroll which forces a choice upon the hearer.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: S2 is treated as a social pathology (complacency) rather than a state of spiritual death.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While using the language of 'Gospel' and 'Luther,' the actantial subject is consistently the human community (Josiah, Luther, 'We') responding to a document. The 'Gospel' is reduced to a 'summons' or 'truth-telling' that we must implement.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: God’s love is free to all those who trust and obey.
The word to Josiah was so that Jerusalem would not be on the make for its own security.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: That word cannot be shredded. It has staying power.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Josiah and Luther are presented as heroic subjects who 'took the scroll seriously' and 'instituted reform,' serving as models for the modern church.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: A theocentric reading would focus on God's faithfulness to His covenant despite Josiah's failure or the King's shredding—God as the one who preserves His Word and His people.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Pressure to perform; 'The crisis of de-form and re-form is upon us.'
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is subsumed by Sociology; salvation is 'recovering the neighborhood'.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative is coherent in its call to action, but theologically incoherent regarding Luther's 'Sola Gratia' which it claims to celebrate while imposing a 'trust and obey' condition.
spanning_punten: The claim that 'God's love is free' followed immediately by 'to those who trust and obey'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The gospel takes the world as a neighborhood... Jesus is the good neighbor because he is the one who shows mercy.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The 'Scroll' provides the Savoir (Knowledge), but the Subject is expected to provide their own Pouvoir (Power).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is described as 'complacency,' 'anxiety,' and 'greed'—social distortions rather than an inherent condition requiring a Savior.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon functions as a 'Recruitment' narrative. The Scroll is the Sender, the Church is the Subject, and the Neighbor is the Object. God is relegated to the background as the one who 'poured out' love in the past.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The Church/Hearer is the subject of all 'reforming' verbs.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Make the Word/Spirit the Subject that reforms the passive Church.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'We must re-form the church,' use 'The Word of God breaks into our complacency to re-form us.'

identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the 'Shredded Scroll' or the 'Vulnerable Neighbor' who is saved by God.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that we are the ones who tried to shred the word, yet God speaks again.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how the 'free love' actually enables a greedy person to become generous (the 'how' of grace).

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Describe the 'Greed System' not just as a social choice but as a 'bondage of the will' that only Christ can break.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: Without a 'Heavy Opponent,' the 'Helper' (Jesus) becomes merely an example rather than a Savior.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: 1. God saves the anxious/greedy church (Soteriology). 2. The church, now free, loves the neighbor (Ethics).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon has high rhetorical power and social relevance, but it risks turning the Reformation into a new Law. By making 'trust and obey' a condition for 'free love,' it undermines the very Lutheran theology it seeks to honor.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, this is a powerful call to social justice. Semiotically, it is a legalistic mandate where the human is the hero.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the history of Josiah; Greimas shows that Josiah is being used as a functional 'Subject-Model' to trigger 'Devoir' in the audience.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that 'The Scroll' is the only actant with true power in the text, yet the preacher tries to transfer that power to the human 'Reformer'.

volledige_subject_lijst: Josiah (renovated, found, took seriously, tore clothes, instituted)
The Church (accommodates, lives in collusion, inhales anxiety)
The Scroll (refuses to be shredded, insists, tells truth)
appendices.notities: The sermon's definition of Gospel as 'hospitality, generosity, forgiveness, justice' is purely actantial (what we do) rather than ontological (who Christ is).
